_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. The Facility Policy

The owners, management, and employees of The Farmers Cooperative Union are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department , or other authorities , to mitigate any release and to minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. 

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers fo sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is stored and distributed for application uses.

The maximum quanity stored would be 83,200 pounds in our 19, 1000 nurse trailers. 

3. The worst-case release scenerio and the alternative release scenario.

A. The worst-case scenerio would be the release of the total contents of a nurse tank released as a gas over ten minutes. The maximum quanity released would be 4400 pounds, which represents the volume of a nurse tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by desigh standards.The distance to the end point ( point of dispersion to 200 ppm ) is .25 miles.

B. The alternative release scenario based on the five-year accident history ( or the most likely potential incident ) is a release from a break in a transfer hose. The distance to end point is .22 miles.

4. The accidental release prvention program. 

 The facility has implemented the provisions of " Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1 ", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA ), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia". 

5. The five year Accident History 

A. There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that : 
- have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or 
- to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, p

roperty damage or environmental damage. 

6. The emergancy response program.

-The facility has:

A. A emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard , 29 CFR 1910.38;

B. Provided state and local authorities the emergancy planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). 

7. Planned changes to improve safety. 

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluation are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no Additional specifis anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
